posts.name: jimfl014
posts.cooked:
Since we started 7 years ago we always used XT60 connectors on all our motors.  It allowed us to teach the skill of soldering and we‚Äôve never had an inspector question those connectors.

This year, I won‚Äôt go into our sob story, we‚Äôve cut corners and used Wago on our CAM bus - no issues so far, and crimp connectors on a new brushless motor/controller we are using this year.

We have had issues with crimps, mostly due to the dependency of forearm strength.

Soldering has it‚Äôs issues in terms of the learning curve, time and quality assurance

I‚Äôm curious what other Teams are using and is soldering a lost art.
If your students are willing to learn, it could be a cool activity.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked: How else would you connect your CAN chain?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
jimfl014:

We have had issues with crimps, mostly due to the dependency of forearm strength.

Use a ratcheting crimper.  That fixes that dependency (it doesn‚Äôt release until it‚Äôs fully crimped).

posts.name: jimfl014
posts.cooked: We use the CAN connector packs, available at CTRE.  This year instead of expanding the number of packs, we used a set of Wagos

posts.name: jimfl014
posts.cooked: Can you suggest a crimper?

posts.name: Jason DesMarais
posts.cooked:
Whether or not soldering is a technique you end up using on your robot, it is still a relevant professional skill and very likely something that students who pursue STEM will end up doing in college or beyond.

There are roughly 93 other threads about crimps and wagos and soldering and whatnot, but if you have an opportunity to teach a useful skill take it!
If you have the time and size of team to teach soldering, I see no reason not to. It will be useful to them  in places other than just robotics.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Different crimpers are used for different connectors‚Äìyou want to use the correct tool for the job.  Some ones I‚Äôve used:

PowerPole contacts: TRIcrimp, the best Powerpole crimping tool for 15, 30 and 45 amp contacts | Powerwerx

PWM-style contacts: Deluxe Crimping Tool

Big wire contacts (battery cables): Powerwerx Handheld Hex Crimper for Large SB Series and Powerpole Connectors | Powerwerx

Other types of contacts, get a set of dies like: CrimpBag, the best Powerpole crimping tool and accessory die sets in a custom nylon gear bag | Powerwerx

The best of course are the official tools the manufacturer of the contacts sells, but they charge an arm and a leg for those, so the above are good low-cost options.

link_counts.title: TRIcrimp, the best Powerpole crimping tool for 15, 30 and 45 amp contacts | Powerwerx
CrimpBag, the best Powerpole crimping tool and accessory die sets in a custom nylon gear bag | Powerwerx
Powerwerx Handheld Hex Crimper for Large SB Series and Powerpole Connectors | Powerwerx

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
Peter_Johnson:

you want to use the correct tool for the job.

And for yellow/blue/red ‚Äúhousehold crimps‚Äù - spring for Klein, don‚Äôt settle for Harbor Freight.

https://www.amazon.com/Klein-Tools-Ratcheting-Crimper-10-22/dp/B07WMB61J5

For 6awg/4awg, the harbor freight hydraulic crimp sets are usually fine. Whatever tool you use, section your first crimp to make sure you‚Äôre getting quality compression inside the joint.

I still teach soldering on and off, depending on the year.

link_counts.title: We dislike these crimps, because they fall off too easily. what are some better ones for connections to sparks

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: WAGO 221 lever nuts are fine for CAN (If you disagree feel free to review the massive CAN thread that was recently posted, but the takeaway is that they work fine as long as you secure them). That said, soldering is useful for tons of other stuff, from simple tasks like soldering CANcoders to making custom circuits. I would highly recommend teaching it, as soldering is a valuable skill for anyone who tinkers in general.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked: For FRC, crimping is essential - definitely the best way to connect wires together and connect wires to motor controllers and FRC-intended sensors. Cultivating some skill at soldering will definitely open up more sensors and ‚Äúcustom circuit‚Äù possibilities than crimping alone.  It can also save a good bit of money for budget-limited teams when using motors which ship without leads.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
jimfl014:

I‚Äôm curious what other Teams are using

Powerpoles, ferrules, ‚Äústandard‚Äù press-fit .1" pitch PWM style connectors, wago-ish wire nut thingies, and a bunch of other things I like less, but which are fine from a functional perspective. Solder thrown in when critical for good measure.

jimfl014:

is soldering a lost art.

I sure hope not! I‚Äôve taught multiple students over the years, and I‚Äôm still a young person by most standards.

I learned because I had a model railroad set growing up, with all the associated tools. Learning to fabricate circuits happened well before I knew how to design them.

I knew far too many students in college who borked up their senior design projects by not knowing how to solder, frying components, then staying up till wee hours of the morning figuring out which component they fried, ordering more, waiting for shipping, trying again‚Ä¶

Getting good at soldering takes time and practice. If you don‚Äôt have a unit at home and projects to learn on, I doubt you‚Äôll get good from the four times a year you have to do it for robotics. From that perspective, I don‚Äôt think you‚Äôll increase your robot‚Äôs reliability by tossing a soldering iron at a new student and saying ‚Äúgo fix it!‚Äù.

But, I‚Äôll fight tooth and nail before it becomes a lost art.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked: Both are useful, both have applications on FRC robots. We teach both.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked: I‚Äôll add my experience with a handful of students getting hired as techs due to the soldering (and crimping and etc) skills they picked up in FRC. For my work at least, our weed-out test is soldering 5 wires to a Dsub power connector. Slam dunk even if you‚Äôve just soldered thru-hole components on a PCB, but an obvious tell if you‚Äôve never picked up an iron.

posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked: Soldering is useful for putting those boards with power pole connectors on the back of 775Pro motors. Aside from that and custom boards, everything on our robot is crimped. But yes, soldering is a very useful skill. However, I‚Äôve seen too many people do it wrong. My first words in teaching soldering are, ‚ÄúThis is not painting. A soldering iron is not a paint brush. Don‚Äôt use it like one.‚Äù I then explain the concept of heat transfer, making a thermal connection, and getting solder to flow.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
gerthworm:

Getting good at soldering takes time and practice. If you don‚Äôt have a unit at home and projects to learn on, I doubt you‚Äôll get good from the four times a year you have to do it for robotics.

+1

Soldering well requires good hand-eye coordination,  good fine motor control (in your hands) and patience. Those born with those particular gifts will pick up soldering skills relatively quickly. Those born with different gifts may struggle, even with good training and practice.

Your team will must be able to make good quality crimps if they want to make up their own 6+ AWG power cables for the battery and for the connections to the main breaker and PDP . Soldering is a ‚Äúnice to have‚Äù skill for most teams I have seen since many aren‚Äôt using that many sensors and some sensors don‚Äôt need soldering. Many of the teams that do use a lot of soldering are also likely to be doing a lot of work in the off-season so they have a better chance to keep in practice.

s-neff:

for yellow/blue/red ‚Äúhousehold crimps‚Äù - spring for Klein

Home Depot sells the same model crimper for the same price. On Amazon, you have the option of purchasing the crimper with an auto-adjusting wire stripper which is a good deal. While the Klein tools are not the ‚Äúofficial tools‚Äù recommended by the connector manufacturers, they are used by people like electricians who make their living using those tools and the price is not that different from the hobby grade ones. The hobby grade ones are hit or miss so just get the Klein crimper.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
philso:

they are used by people like electricians who make their living using those tools

I would be overjoyed to find a sparky using the above linked crimpers. Most of them seem to get by fine with much less, i.e.: various random pliers and those weird combo wire stripper/crimper/screw cutters.

Still, spring for the Klein. Elechickens have messed up enough to know what does and doesn‚Äôt work for them. Most of us aren‚Äôt lucky(?) enough to have that experience.

posts.name: Jim Forbes
posts.cooked:
I guess my brothers and I were spoiled as kids‚Ä¶we got to build Heathkits, although most of our soldering was on other homebrew projects, mostly using surplus parts.

I always take advantage of the opportunity to have a student solder something‚Ä¶it‚Äôs a great skill, and will probably be needed for a long time.

posts.name: jimfl014
posts.cooked:
Thanks for all the feedback!

It‚Äôs good to hear that soldering skills do still have value - so we will continue teaching it.

I remember soldering up my senior design project and I recall their were several people in that class that struggled with it.  Now, even with cheater glasses I can‚Äôt see that great to do it anymore.

We will also be investing in the Klein crimper as that is also a skill.
